claim: Donald Trump was the most recent U.S. president not selected as Time's Person of the Year.

supporting.text: Donald Trump was the U.S. president from 2017 to 2021 and was not selected as Time's Person of the Year during or after his presidency.

attacks.text: Donald Trump was the U.S. president from 2017 to 2021 and was not selected as Time's Person of the Year during or after his presidency.
Time's Person of the Year is not necessarily awarded to the U.S. president, so Trump's absence does not uniquely identify him as the most recent non-selected president.
The claim specifies 'most recent U.S. president not selected,' which is factually correct regardless of Time's selection criteria for non-presidents.
Time's Person of the Year selections are subjective and not a definitive measure of presidential significance, making the claim misleading.
The claim is a factual statement about Time's selections, not an evaluation of presidential significance, so subjectivity is irrelevant.

supporting.text: Time's Person of the Year for 2020 was not Donald Trump, but instead was awarded to Joe Biden and Kamala Harris.

attacks.text: Time's Person of the Year for 2020 was not Donald Trump, but instead was awarded to Joe Biden and Kamala Harris.

supporting.text: No former U.S. president has been selected as Time's Person of the Year after leaving office since Donald Trump left office in 2021.

attacks.text: No former U.S. president has been selected as Time's Person of the Year after leaving office since Donald Trump left office in 2021.
Time's Person of the Year is not exclusively awarded to current leaders, and former presidents could still be selected in the future.

The selection criteria for Time's Person of the Year focus on influence within the given year, making it unlikely for a former president to be selected post-office unless they had extraordinary impact.
Historical precedent shows that former U.S. presidents have rarely, if ever, been selected as Time's Person of the Year after leaving office.
Exceptions to historical precedent could occur if a former president becomes highly influential post-office, such as through activism or major public events.
